questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It originates through Killian's dehiscence, which is a site of weakness present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts:

  1. Upper part - thyropharyngeus, made of oblique fibres.
  2. Lower part - cricopharyngeus, made of transverse fibres.

Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal's collar or Casal's necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

questions.text: Non-sense mutation is seen in _____________.
questions.solution:
Non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA (i.e., the region of the DNA that  codes for proteins) are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. Because these mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein, they are often referred to as missense mutations.                                                                                                                                                                            Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia, which is characterized by point mutation affecting the β-globin chain of the hemoglobin, where the nucleotide triplet CTC (or GAG in mRNA), which encodes glutamic acid, is changed to CAC (or GUG in mRNA), which encodes valine.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

The illustration below shows various types of point mutations:

Other options:

  • Option b: The α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.
  • Option c: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation.
  • Option d: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by​ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

Trichuris trichiura are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled, and have a pair of polar plugs at each end. They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

It causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse.Trichuriasis is caused by the T. trichura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth and developmental defects.

Diagnosis:

Fecal smears showing barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichura. The eggs of Trichuris trichura does not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. 

Treatment: Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days; for all ages)

The image of egg of trichuris trichura is given below:

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is indicated in the management of hyperthyroidism.

Other options

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers are fetopathic and can cause fetal growth retardation and hypoplasia of organs. 

Statins can cause Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the hanging mark is false?

choices.text: The most common position of the knot is under the chin
The gap in the hanging mark indicates the point of suspension
The hanging mark is situated above the thyroid cartilage
The mark dries to a parchment like consistency post-mortem

questions.solution:
The knot in a suicidal hanging is much less likely to be found under the chin than in other positions - behind the ear or at the occiput.

Hanging mark

  • The hanging mark almost never completely encircles the neck unless a slipknot is used.
  • In most instances the point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark.
  • This gap is usually seen at one or other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often it is under the chin.
  • The hanging mark is situated higher on the neck than in strangulation, usually being directly under the chin anteriorly, passing round beneath the jawbones and rising at the sides or back of the neck to the usual gap under the knot.
  • The mark may be abraded, brown and dried to a parchment-like consistency after death.
  • There may be a narrow red zone either above or below (or both sides) the ligature mark. This is not an indicator of vital reaction but is due to the displacement of blood laterally from under the zone of maximum pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
  • Nasal polyps
  • Mucocele 
  • Control of epistaxis 
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.text: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears as shown below.  What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil (image) suggest a diagnosis of uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis.

Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect. 

Cycloplegics like 1% atropine, relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation.

Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. 

Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor), are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of 500 patients having carcinoma lung and another group of 300 was chosen from the general population. Both these groups were questioned on their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case–control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people constitute the controls, and the study is done from effect to cause as the disease has already occurred.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding phase.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: From the following epidemic curve, identify the type of epidemic depicted.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen on the thumb. The deformity has flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint hyperextension at the interphalangeal (IP) joint

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. During the evaluation, the patient opens his eyes in response to voice and says inappropriate words. He is unable to move his right arm but extends his left arm to a painful stimulus on his right arm. What is the GCS score of this patient?
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient described is 8 (E3 V3 M2).

In the case elaborated above, the score allotted is :

  • Eye-opening to speech—3
  • Inappropriate words—3
  • Extensor response to painful stimuli—2

Patients scoring a GCS of 3 or 4 have an 85% chance of dying or remaining vegetative.

However, scores >11 indicate only a 5–10% likelihood of death or vegetative state and an 85% chance of moderate disability or good recovery.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with persistent headaches over the last 1 month. Her father and paternal uncle suffered from kidney disease and both died in their 50's of a 'brain bleed'. Her blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg and had also been elevated during a previous visit. Which of the following investigations should be avoided in this patient?

choices.text: Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen
Non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen
MR angiography of the cerebral vasculature

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). These patients usually have impaired renal function. Hence, contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) would usually be avoided due to the risk of contrast nephrotoxicity.

The following investigations are done in patients with ADPKD:

  • USG abdomen - for screening and diagnosis
  • Non-contrast CT abdomen - more sensitive and picks up cysts of smaller size
  • MR-angiography of brain - pre-symptomatic screening for intracerebral aneurysms

questions.text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Chronic interstitial pneumonitis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
    • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Patent Ductus arteriosus
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism (Grave’s disease)
    • Thyroid acropachy
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Skin disease
    • Palmoplantar keratoderma
    • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Thymus cancer
    • Hodgkin disease
    • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable.  Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting. Testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Signs seen on torsion of the testis are:

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis

Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended. The typical window of opportunity for surgical intervention and testicular salvage is 6 hours from onset of pain.

Testicular torsion is a clinical diagnosis and an emergency, therefore no time is wasted in performing the other investigations.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from an undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis.

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
  • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure

Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen.

Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude (≥180 mmHg) contractions with an increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure (≥26 mmHg). Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma will not have any issues with the motility or peristalsis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
questions.solution:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–7 days in the uterine cavity.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Blastocyst starts to establish contact with the uterine wall.
  •  Adhesion: Increase in the physical interaction between the blastocyst and the uterine epithelium.
  •  Invasion: Syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts penetrate and invade the endometrium.

Prior to implantation, the endometrium is primed with estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum. This uterine receptivity is maximal from the 20th - 24th days of the endometrial cycle. Failure of embryo transfer during this time period may result in repeated implantation failure in IVF patients. 

Adherence of the blastocyst to the uterine cavity is a result of interaction between the cell-surface receptors at the implantation site and the blastocyst receptors.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: A woman recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in axonotmesis. There is an axonal disruption (inner axon is damaged) and loss of conductivity, with an intact outer sheath. 

Axonotmesis (axonal interruption): There is a loss of conduction, but the continuity of the nerve is maintained and the neural tubes are intact. There is disruption of the axon i.e., the continuity of the axon is broken. But the endoneurium and perineurium are intact, maintaining the continuity of the nerve. It occurs following trauma such as closed fractures and dislocations.

Distal to the lesion, Wallerian degeneration of the disrupted axon occurs, where axons disintegrate and are resorbed by phagocytes. It is then followed by axonal regeneration where numerous fine unmyelinated fibres grow from the proximal stumps to the endoneurial tubes.

Other options:

Option A- Neurapraxia is the reversible physiological nerve conduction block causing some loss of sensation and muscle power. There is spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks. It occurs following prolonged compression, as in Saturday night palsy, and crutch palsy. Here, there is segmental demyelination but the axon is intact. Nerve conduction is slowed because of the loss of myelin. It is followed by the regeneration of the myelin.

Option B- Neurotmesis is the complete transection of the nerve trunk. It is usually associated with open wounds. The endoneurial tubes are destroyed and the scar tissue prevents the regenerating axons from entering the distal segment. The regenerating fibers mingle with proliferating Schwann cells and fibroblasts to form a neuroma at the site of injury.

Option D- Axonapraxia is a disruption to the axoplasmic flow of neurochemicals temporarily.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic requesting liposuction. She feels she is obese and would like to get rid of the "excess fat". On further enquiry, she reveals a habit of eating high-calorie food multiple times a month which she later regrets and skipping meals at times. Her BMI is 23. An examination of her hands is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders - fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders - carbamazepine

questions.text: Which is the shortest acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinylcholine) is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid-onset (30–60secs) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing & non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant: 

  • Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant:

Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Doxacurium

questions.text: Which is the most common organism implicated in the condition depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows rough finger-like growth over the vulva which is suggestive of condyloma acuminata. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

It is also called genital/venereal warts and has high infectivity. It is acquired most commonly after sexual contact but may also occur non-sexually.

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds are used in PET scan?
questions.solution:
PET involves the use of a radiolabelled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) which is injected intravenously. This compound is taken up and broken down in the cells.

It is based on the principle that tumour cells have a high metabolic rate, and hence this compound is also metabolised by tumour cells. FDG is metabolised to FDG-6-phosphate which cannot be further metabolized by tumour cells. Hence it accumulates in tumour cells and can be measured and quantified.

The applications of PET include:

  • Oncologic:
    • Detection, staging, drug response
    • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence
  • Neurologic:
    • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
    • Localisation of seizure focus in the interictal phase
    • Localising eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)
  • Cardiac: Identification of hibernating myocardium
